core_concept.principle: Electromagnetism unifies electric and magnetic phenomena through fundamental relationships: charges create electric fields, moving charges create magnetic fields, and changing magnetic fields create electric fields. These interconnected phenomena govern most modern technologies.
core_concept.explanation: This comprehensive review integrates the separate concepts studied throughout the electromagnetism unit, emphasizing their interconnections and preparing students for the unified treatment in Maxwell's equations and advanced physics.

worked_examples.title: Velocity Selector and Mass Spectrometer Combination
worked_examples.problem: A velocity selector uses E=1200 V/m and B=0.04T. Selected particles enter a 0.2T magnetic field region and curve with radius 0.15m. The particles are singly ionized atoms. Determine: (a) Selected velocity, (b) Mass of atoms, (c) Identify the element.
worked_examples.final_answer: Selected velocity = 30,000 m/s, Mass = 1.6×10⁻²⁵ kg (96.4 u), Element: Molybdenum isotope. This demonstrates complete particle analysis using combined electric and magnetic fields.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Velocity selector and mass spectrometer integration

worked_examples.title: Complex Circuit with Magnetic Application
worked_examples.problem: A circuit powers an electromagnet: 24V source with internal resistance 1Ω, series resistor 5Ω, electromagnet coil resistance 8Ω with 500 turns, area 0.02m². The electromagnet creates a field that deflects an electron beam. Calculate: (a) Circuit current, (b) Magnetic field strength, (c) Force on electrons moving at 10⁷ m/s perpendicular to field.
worked_examples.final_answer: Current = 1.71A, Magnetic field = 5.39 mT, Electron force = 8.62×10⁻¹⁵ N. Demonstrates circuit-field-force integration.

worked_examples.title: Electric Motor Design Analysis
worked_examples.problem: Design a simple DC motor: Rectangular coil 0.1m × 0.15m, 200 turns, in 0.5T field. Maximum available current 2A. Calculate: (a) Maximum magnetic moment, (b) Maximum torque, (c) Required voltage if coil resistance is 10Ω, (d) Power input at maximum torque.

step_by_step.explanation: Real motors have lower efficiency due to friction, resistance losses, and non-ideal field alignment

worked_examples.final_answer: μ_max = 6 A·m², τ_max = 3 N·m, V_required = 20V, P_input = 40W. Practical design would need safety margins and efficiency factors.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Motor design combining magnetic moment, torque, and circuit analysis

image.caption: Motor design integrates magnetic principles with electrical power requirements

worked_examples.title: Capacitor and Magnetic Field Interaction
worked_examples.problem: A 100μF capacitor charged to 50V discharges through a 0.1m straight wire in 0.2T perpendicular magnetic field. The wire has resistance 0.5Ω. Calculate: (a) Initial current, (b) Initial magnetic force on wire, (c) Estimate motion if wire is free to move (mass 0.01kg).

step_by_step.explanation: Wire would accelerate initially at 200 m/s², but force decreases rapidly as capacitor discharges

worked_examples.final_answer: Initial current = 100A, Initial force = 2N, Initial acceleration = 200 m/s². The wire experiences brief strong acceleration followed by rapid decay as capacitor discharges.

worked_examples.title: Comprehensive Circuit and Field Problem
worked_examples.problem: A particle accelerator section: 50kV potential difference accelerates protons into 0.8T uniform magnetic field region. Calculate: (a) Proton speed after acceleration, (b) Radius of circular path, (c) Period of revolution, (d) Required magnetic field for 0.5m radius.
worked_examples.final_answer: Proton speed = 3.10×10⁶ m/s, Radius = 4.04 cm, Period = 82.0 ns, Field for 0.5m radius = 0.0646 T. Demonstrates complete particle dynamics analysis.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Comprehensive particle acceleration and magnetic deflection analysis

image.caption: Particle accelerator analysis combines electric acceleration with magnetic confinement

worked_examples.title: Experimental Design: e/m Ratio Measurement
worked_examples.problem: Design an experiment to measure electron charge-to-mass ratio using magnetic deflection. Specify: (a) Required equipment, (b) Experimental procedure, (c) Measurements needed, (d) Calculation method, (e) Expected sources of error.

step_by_step.explanation: Electron gun with known acceleration voltage, Helmholtz coils for uniform magnetic field, fluorescent screen to observe electron path, power supplies, measuring tools
Accelerate electrons through known voltage, apply perpendicular magnetic field, measure curvature radius of electron path
Acceleration voltage V, magnetic field strength B, radius of curvature r
From eV = ½mv² and r = mv/(eB), eliminate v to get e/m = 2V/(B²r²)
Field non-uniformity, voltage measurement accuracy, radius measurement precision, relativistic effects at high speeds

worked_examples.final_answer: e/m = 2V/(B²r²). Expected value ~1.76×10¹¹ C/kg. Careful measurement of V, B, and r with error analysis gives experimental verification of this fundamental constant.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Experimental design combining multiple electromagnetism principles

image.caption: Electron charge-to-mass ratio measurement demonstrates fundamental electromagnetic principles

summary: This comprehensive review integrates all electromagnetism concepts: electric fields and potentials, DC circuit analysis, magnetic fields and forces, and their practical applications. Mastery involves solving complex multi-step problems, designing experiments, and understanding the interconnected nature of electromagnetic phenomena. Systematic approaches, deliberate practice, and multiple assessment methods ensure solid preparation for advanced topics including AC circuits, electromagnetic waves, and Maxwell's equations. The unified understanding of electromagnetism developed here forms the foundation for most modern technologies and advanced physics study.
